description: From Middle English breef, breve, bref, from Old French brief, bref, from Latin brevis (“short”), from Proto-Indo-European *mréǵʰus (“short, brief”). Doublet of merry.

entries.meaning: Of short duration; happening quickly. [from 15th c.]
examples: Her reign was brief but spectacular.

entries.meaning: Concise; taking few words. [from 15th c.]
examples: His speech of acceptance was brief but moving.

entries.meaning: Occupying a small distance, area or spatial extent; short. [from 17th c.]
examples: Her skirt was extremely brief but doubtless cool.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Rife; common; prevalent.

adverbs.description: brief (comparative more brief, superlative most brief)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, poetic) Briefly.
(obsolete, poetic) Soon; quickly.
(law) A writ summoning one to answer; an official letter or mandate.
(law) An answer to any action.
examples: A written answer or any other brief shall be submitted to the court while allowing a period necessary for the opponent to make preparations with regard to the matters stated therein.

entries.meaning: (law) A memorandum of points of fact or of law for use in conducting a case.
(by extension, figurative) A position of interest or advocacy.
(law) An attorney's legal argument in written form for submission to a court.
(English law) The material relevant to a case, delivered by a solicitor to the barrister who is counsel for the case.
(English law, slang) A barrister who is counsel for a party in a legal action.
A short news story or report.
(usually in the plural) underwear briefs.
examples: I wear boxers under trousers but for sports I usually wear a brief.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A summary, précis or epitome; an abridgement or abstract.
examples: […]  euen ſo it fareth with mee, who béeing about to anatomize Abſurditie, am vrged to take a view of ſundry mens vanitie, a ſuruey of their follie, a briefe of their barbariſme  […]

entries.meaning: (UK, historical) A letter patent, from proper authority, authorizing a collection or charitable contribution of money in churches, for any public or private purpose.
(slang) A ticket of any type.

verbs.description: brief (third-person singular simple present briefs, present participle briefing, simple past and past participle briefed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To summarize a recent development to some person with decision-making power.
examples: The U.S. president was briefed on the military coup and its implications on African stability.

entries.meaning: (transitive, law) To write a legal argument and submit it to a court.
